captions.text:
If you look at the games, you could say the
Wii U was of Nintendo’s best launches. In

fact, it...kind of felt like an apology for
all the games Nintendo didn’t have on its

previous hardware. “Hey, sorry we didn’t
have any of those big third-party games. So,

uh...here’s Mass Effect, Call Of Duty, Assassin’s
Creed and a little Darksiders."
“Oh, and here’s Batman: Arkham City.”

Arkham City is one of the major games to launch
on Wii U after having already been released.

Gamers who buy multiple consoles probably
scoff at this, but for the people who only

buy one console—and yeah, most consumers
only buy one—having these games rereleased

on a Nintendo console is, in fact, a big deal.
It’s introducing them to an entirely new
audience.

And if you’re part of that audience, this
is the one you should prioritize.

Because Batman: Arkham City is a stunning
game.

Of course, the drawback is that...much like
Mass Effect, Arkham City releases with no

context on Wii U. Its story is one of its
highlights, but since its set immediately

after the events of the first game, you might
be left out in the cold a bit. Nonetheless,

the game really is brilliant in terms of its
story and setting, and I think even without

playing the original, you’ll still be captivated
by the world Arkham City creates.

Speaking of that world...that’s the brilliance
of the game. Arkham City is this massive prison

built right in the center of Gotham...a kind
of prison community, walled off from the rest

of the city. It’s brilliant for a few reasons.
One, this decaying city of prisoners sets

the perfect stage for the game’s dark tone.
And two, it’s the perfect excuse for putting

every freaking Batman villain imaginable into
this game.

It makes sense, because...this is a city of
villains.

From the moment the game begins, the city
itself just pulls you in. It’s chaotic,

it’s seductive...it’s a nightmare you
can walk around in. And the deeper you delve

into Arkham City, the deeper you can go. The
place is massive, and since its a prison,

Batman has this seemingly never-ending list
of missions and side-quests.

In fact, there’s even a bit of Metroid to
Arkham City. Places that were out of reach

are accessible with the right gadget, so you’re
constantly finding new places...each darker

than the last. In fact, Arkham itself becomes
its own fascinating, bizarre character.
In a cast of many fascinating, bizarre characters.

So Wii U owners are getting a phenomenal beat
‘em up, but fortunately, they’re also

getting a somewhat updated beat ‘em up.
The expansion, Harley Quinn’s Revenge, is

included on Wii U, as well as the extra challenge
rooms and character skins. Although the GamePad

use isn’t spectacular, it does have some
uses. Specifically, for sonar, which is nice...and

of course, you can also play the entire game
on its screen.

I get it, alright? It’s an old game...at
least, by gaming standards. But that doesn’t

make this thing any less impressive. Not only
does it create a stunning atmosphere, driven

by its rich characters and setting, but it’s
also a great beat ‘em up. It’s this wonderful

nexus of simple controls, elegant gameplay
and captivating content, and it’s a must-have

on Wii U. It may not be the launch title you
need, but it’s the launch title you deserve.
Or something. It’s Batman: Arkham City.

title: CGR Undertow - BATMAN: ARKHAM CITY: ARMORED EDITION review for Nintendo Wii U
